sen.j: 吉野神宮（よしのじんぐう）は、奈良県吉野郡吉野町に鎮座する後醍醐天皇を祭神とする神社。
sen.e: Yoshino-jingu Shrine located in Yoshino-cho, Yoshino-gun, Nara Prefecture is a shrine dedicated to Emperor Godaigo an enshrined deity..
Yoshino-jingu Shrine located in Yoshino-cho, Yoshino-gun, Nara Prefecture is a shrine whose enshrined deity is Emperor Godaigo.
sen.cmt: a shrine whose enshrined deity is Emperor Godaigo.としました。
sen.e: Yoshino-jingu Shrine located in Yoshino-cho, Yoshino-gun, Nara Prefecture is a shrine whose enshrined deity is Emperor Godaigo.

sen.j: 建武中興十五社の一社で、旧社格は官幣大社である。
sen.e: It is one of the fifteen Shinto shrines enshrining the royalty and military commanders in the Southern Court side who contributed to the Kenmu Restoration and its former shrine ranking was Kanpei-taisha (large-scale state shrine).

It is one of the fifteen Shinto shrines enshrining the royalty and military commanders in the Southern Court side who contributed to the Kenmu Restoration, and it was formerly ranked as Kanpei-taisha (large-scale state shrine).
sen.cmt: 旧社格は・・・（もともとの社格は）：, and it was formerly ranked as Kanpei-taisha (large-scale state shrine)としました。
sen.e: It is one of the fifteen Shinto shrines enshrining the royalty and military commanders in the Southern Court side who contributed to the Kenmu Restoration, and it was formerly ranked as Kanpei-taisha (large-scale state shrine).
Its former name of the shrine was Yoshino no miya.
Its former name of the shrine was Yoshino no miya.
Its former name of the shrine was Yoshino no miya.
History
History
History

sen.j: 南朝 (日本)の後村上天皇は、父の後醍醐天皇が延元4年（1339年）に崩御した後、その像を吉水院に安置した。
sen.e: Emperor Gomurakami of the Southern Court (Japan), after the death of his father the Emperor Godaigo in 1339, enshrined the statue of his father in Kissuiin.
Emperor Gomurakami of the Southern Court (Japan), after the death of his father the Emperor Godaigo in 1339, enshrined the statue of his father in Kissuiin.
Emperor Gomurakami of the Southern Court (Japan), after the death of his father the Emperor Godaigo in 1339, enshrined the statue of his father in Kissuiin.

sen.j: 以降、仏教式の供養が行われていた。
sen.e: It held memorial services according to Buddhism after that.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文例外対処
sen.e: Since then, memorial services had been practiced according to Buddhist rite.
sen.cmt: Since then, memorial services had been practiced としました。
sen.e: Since then, memorial services had been practiced according to Buddhist rite.

sen.j: 神仏分離により明治6年（1873年）、吉水神社に改称して後醍醐天皇を祭神とする神社となった。
sen.e: It changed its name to Yoshimizu-jinja Shrine after the separation of Buddhism and Shintoism in 1873 and became a shine whose enshrined deity is Emperor Godaigo.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文例外対処
sen.e: It changed its name to Yoshimizu-jinja Shrine after the separation of Buddhism and Shintoism in 1873 and became a shine that enshrined Emperor Godaigo.
sen.cmt: 上部列の表現と重複するのでa shrine that enshrined Emperor Godaigoとしました。
sen.e: It changed its name to Yoshimizu-jinja Shrine after the separation of Buddhism and Shintoism in 1873 and became a shine that enshrined Emperor Godaigo.

sen.j: これとは別に、明治22年（1889年）に後醍醐天皇を祀る官幣中社吉野宮の創建が、明治天皇の意向で決定した。
sen.e: Aside from this, the foundation of Kanpei Chusha shrine (middle-scale government shrines) Yoshino no miya was decided in accordance with the Emperor Meiji's wishes in 1889.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文例外対処
sen.e: Aside from this, the foundation of Yoshino no miya Shrine as one of Kanpei-chusha (middle-scale government shrines) was decided in accordance with the Emperor Meiji's wishes in 1889.
sen.cmt: the foundation of Yoshino no miya Shrine as one of Kanpei-chusha (middle-scale government shrines) としました。
sen.e: Aside from this, the foundation of Yoshino no miya Shrine as one of Kanpei-chusha (middle-scale government shrines) was decided in accordance with the Emperor Meiji's wishes in 1889.

sen.j: 明治25年（1892年）に社殿が竣工して、吉水神社から後醍醐天皇像を移して遷座祭が斎行された。
sen.e: After the main building was completed in 1892, the statue of Emperor Godaigo was moved from Yoshimizu-jinja Shrine and Senza-sai Festival (Festival for transfer of a Shinto shrine) was held.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文例外対処
sen.e: After the main building was completed in 1892, the statue of Emperor Godaigo was moved from Yoshimizu-jinja Shrine and Senza-sai (a ceremony to commemorate the transfer of a Shinto shrine) was held
sen.cmt: Senza-sai (a ceremony to commemorate the transfer of a Shinto shrine) としました。
sen.e: After the main building was completed in 1892, the statue of Emperor Godaigo was moved from Yoshimizu-jinja Shrine and Senza-sai (a ceremony to commemorate the transfer of a Shinto shrine) was held

sen.j: 明治34年（1901年）に官幣大社に昇格し、大正7年（1918年）に吉野神宮に改称した。
sen.e: It was promoted to Kanpeitaisha in 1901 and changed its name to Yoshino-jingu Shrine in 1918.
It was raised to Kanpei-taisha in 1901 and changed its name to Yoshino-jingu Shrine in 1918.
It was raised to Kanpei-taisha in 1901 and changed its name to Yoshino-jingu Shrine in 1918.
In 1923, its precinct was enlarged.
In 1923, its precinct was enlarged.
In 1923, its precinct was enlarged.

sen.j: 1927年（昭和2年）現本殿上棟、祝詞舎完成。
sen.e: In 1927, the framework of the current Honden (main shrine) and the construction of Noritoya Hall were completed.
In 1927, the framework of the current Honden (main shrine) and the construction of Noritoya Hall (a hall for Shinto prayer) were completed.
sen.cmt: Noritoya Hall (a hall for Shinto prayer)としました。
sen.e: In 1927, the framework of the current Honden (main shrine) and the construction of Noritoya Hall (a hall for Shinto prayer) were completed.
In 1928, the construction of existing Haiden (a hall of worship) was completed.
In 1928, the construction of existing Haiden (a hall of worship) was completed.
In 1928, the construction of existing Haiden (a hall of worship) was completed.
In 1929, the construction of Kando was completed.
In 1929, the construction of Shinmon (shrine gate) was completed.
In 1929, the construction of Shinmon (shrine gate) was completed.
In 1930, the construction of Otorii (a large gateway to a Shinto shrine) was completed.
In 1930, the construction of Otorii (a large gateway to a Shinto shrine) was completed.
In 1930, the construction of Otorii (a large gateway to a Shinto shrine) was completed.
In 1998, existing itsuki no yakata was completed.
In 1998, the existing Saikan (a purification hall for Shinto priests) was completed.
sen.cmt: 斎館：itsuki no yakata→Saikan (a purification hall for Shinto priests)
sen.e: In 1998, the existing Saikan (a purification hall for Shinto priests) was completed.

sen.j: 4月第3日曜日 春の大祭（建武中興記念祭）
sen.e: The third Sunday of April: Haru-no-taisai Grand Spring Festival (the Kemmu Restoration anniversary memorial festival)
The third Sunday of April: Haru-no-taisai Grand Spring Festival (the Kemmu Restoration anniversary memorial festival)
The third Sunday of April: Haru-no-taisai Grand Spring Festival (the Kemmu Restoration anniversary memorial festival)

On July 31: Nagoshi-taisai (summer grand purification)
sen.cmt: Nagoshi Grand Spring→Nagoshi-taisai (summer grand purification) 夏越の祓と呼ばれ、下列の大祓（年越しの祓）と対になっているようですので、カッコ内は対になっていることが分かるようにしました。
sen.e: On July 31: Nagoshi-taisai (summer grand purification)

sen.j: 9月27日 秋の大祭（後醍醐天皇崩御日）
sen.e: On September 27: autumn major festival (the anniversary of Emperor Godaigo's death)
On September 27: autumn major festival (the anniversary of Emperor Godaigo's death)

On December 23: Tencho-sai Festival (to celebrate the Emperor)

On December 31: Oharae (year-end grand purification)
sen.cmt: Oharae (the great purification)→Oharae (year-end grand purification) 夏越大祭（の祓）と対になっているようですので、あわせました。

sen.j: 本殿・拝殿・神門はかつて後醍醐天皇が京都の御所へ帰還される事を熱望されていた心情を汲んで、京都の方角を向き、北向きに建てられている。
sen.e: Honden (main hall), Haiden (a hall of worship), and Shinmon (shrine gate) stand facing north in the direction of Kyoto considering Emperor Godaigo's ardent wish to return to gosho (Imperial Palace) in Kyoto.

Honden (main hall), Haiden (a hall of worship), and Shinmon (shrine gate) are oriented to the north in the direction of Kyoto, which was a layout adopted in order to meet Emperor Godaigo's ardent wish to return to gosho (Imperial Palace) in Kyoto.
sen.cmt: are oriented to the north in the direction of Kyoto, which was a layout adopted in order to meet Emperor Godaigo's ardent wishとしました。
sen.e: Honden (main hall), Haiden (a hall of worship), and Shinmon (shrine gate) are oriented to the north in the direction of Kyoto, which was a layout adopted in order to meet Emperor Godaigo's ardent wish to return to gosho (Imperial Palace) in Kyoto.
It was built of all cypress.
The buildings are all-cypress.
The buildings are all-cypress.

sen.j: 近代神社建築の代表とされる。
sen.e: It is said to be a typical of the modern shrine architecture.
It is said to be a typical of the modern shrine architecture.
It is said to be a typical of the modern shrine architecture.
It is a place well known for beautiful cherry blossoms.
It is a place well known for beautiful cherry blossoms.
It is a place well known for beautiful cherry blossoms.

sen.j: 金剛山 (金剛山地)・大和葛城山が遠望できる。
sen.e: Kongo-san Mountain (Kongo mountainous district) and Yamato Katsuragi Moutain can be viewed from a distance.
The shrine commands a distance view of Kongo-san Mountain (Kongo mountainous district) and Yamato Katsuragi Mountain.
The shrine commands a distance view of Kongo-san Mountain (Kongo mountainous district) and Yamato Katsuragi Mountain.
Three Essha (auxiliary shrine dedicated to a deity close-related to that of a main shrine)
Three Sessha (auxiliary shrine dedicated to a deity close-related to that of a main shrine)
Three Sessha (auxiliary shrine dedicated to a deity close-related to that of a main shrine)

sen.j: 御影・船岡・滝桜の3社が並ぶ。
sen.e: The three shrines of Goei, Funaoka, and Takizakura stand side by side.
The three auxiliary shrines, Goei, Funaoka and Takizakura, stand side by side.
sen.cmt: three auxiliary shrines, Goei, Funaoka and Takizakura, としました。
sen.e: The three auxiliary shrines, Goei, Funaoka and Takizakura, stand side by side.

sen.j: 祭神は南朝方で活躍した、日野資朝、日野俊基、児島範長、児島高徳、桜山茲俊、土居通益、得能通綱。
sen.e: Their enshrined deities are Suketomo HINO, Toshimoto HINO, Norinaga KOJIMA, Takanori KOJIMA, Shigetoshi SAKURAYAMA, Michimasu DOI, and Michitsuna TOKUNO who made showing in the Southern Court.

Their enshrined deities are those who performed distinguished services in the Southern Court: Suketomo HINO, Toshimoto HINO, Norinaga KOJIMA, Takanori KOJIMA, Shigetoshi SAKURAYAMA, Michimasu DOI, and Michitsuna TOKUNO.
sen.cmt: Their enshrined deities are those who performed distinguished services in the Southern Court: としました。
sen.e: Their enshrined deities are those who performed distinguished services in the Southern Court: Suketomo HINO, Toshimoto HINO, Norinaga KOJIMA, Takanori KOJIMA, Shigetoshi SAKURAYAMA, Michimasu DOI, and Michitsuna TOKUNO.
